Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story:
I wiped the sweat from my brow as I glanced at the notice board during our lunch break. The foreman had posted about an optional training session next week—attendance wasn’t mandatory, but everyone knew showing up meant you were serious about your job. The guys were already talking about it, making plans to go together, and I felt the unspoken pressure to join them, to prove I was committed to the team.

But tonight, my mind was elsewhere. The community study circle was meeting at the mosque, and they’d be discussing verses from the Quran I hadn’t yet read. As a Muslim, I was expected to recite and reflect on these verses, to come prepared and contribute thoughtfully. I could already imagine the gentle disappointment in my imam’s eyes if I showed up unprepared, the sense of letting down my brothers and myself.

The weight of both expectations pressed on me. I wanted to be a good worker, respected by my team, but I also wanted to honor my faith and grow spiritually. My thoughts tangled as I tried to figure out how to meet both demands, feeling the tension build inside me as the evening approached.
